1 | Brazil doing very well with the reduction in free shipping threshold, strong growth in buyers with higher conversion rates, redemption, buying more often, more items sold, and strong GMV growth, accelerating growth and gaining market share

The recent reduction in the free shipping threshold in Brazil has already delivered strong results with both GMV and items sold accelerating in the quarter.  We also saw a strong growth in buyers with improved conversion rates, redemption and frequency of purchase. Seller's are also benefiting from the increase in demand of the lower threshold is generating.
As you heard, we're very excited about the results of Q3, in particular, with the results of the strategic investment that we're making the lowering of the free ship interest in Brazil has enabled us to accelerate growth in the marketplace and to continue to gain market share, which, by the way, grew by double over the past 5 years.

2 | More sellers coming to MELI at the lower price ranges (vs Shopee), higher volumes have reduced unit shopping costs in Brazil by 8% QoQ with slow deliveries leveraging on unused capacity

More sellers are coming to our platform and the number of listings has increased sharply in the BRL 19 to BRL 79 price range. Higher transaction volumes helped us reduce unit shipping costs in Brazil by 8%, with slow deliveries enabling us to leverage on the unused capacity.  Brand preference scores reached new record highs across the region, helped by our marketing investments and preshipment policies. So the decline in cost per shipment, 8% QoQ in Brazil, it's a great result for us.

3 | Volume and revenue growth is helping to dilute fixed costs of logistics operations and to use spare capacity and be more efficient, expect unit shipping costs to trend lower over time

the extraordinary growth that we're seeing in volume is helping us dilute fixed costs of our logistic operations has also enabled us to use spare capacity and be more efficient in the way we run our operation in addition to the things that we do on a day-to-day basis in terms of improving efficiencies. So I think that's, for the most part, the main explanation for the lowering of cost. There is some room to continue optimizing the low shipping method in the future, but that will take some more time. I think for the most part, the decrease in cost is related to scale

Bear in mind that this is not only impacting slow shipments, but this is a decline of the total cost per shipment in a country in which we are operating and dealing with strong pressure from -- coming from the extra volume. We believe that unit shipping costs should trend downwards over time, although this might not be a straight line.

4 | Similar to prior investments, Brazil will have near-term compression, but not managing it for short-term margin but for long-term value creation

Last year, you saw when we invested on credit card, it requires some margin compression -- resulting in margin compression. But now as Osvaldo mentioned, the credit card is starting to mature and that tons around. This quarter, we invested significantly on the lowering of free shipping. As you can see, had very strong results related to that with not only GMV but if you look at items sold in Brazil, it accelerated from 26% last quarter to 42% this quarter.

So very strong acceleration of items and volume, new users, more engagement, better conversion rate. We have all-time high NPS levels in Brazil because of this measure. So I think it's important to put that in context. We are not managing the business for short-term margin. We are managing for long-term value creation.

5 | Not afraid of short term margin pressure, long term optimistic about the margin profile

And we think that if we continue to sustain the levels of growth that we are delivering, we are in the right track.  As we said in the past, we are not going to hesitate to invest behind that even if we put some short-term margin pressure. But in the long term, we continue to be very optimistic about the margin profile of our business as we continue to scale the business and as some of the investments that we're making continue to mature, such as the case of the credit card and 1P investments and many other things that we're doing throughout the ecosystem.

6 | MELI wants to have the best possible value proposition for buyers and sellers on their platform, best speed, price, and payment alternatives, driving them to buy more

Let me first start saying that this short-term initiative that you are starting to test for a handful of months as we -- as our competition is also testing their own initiatives for the same period.  So as we said consistently over time, we want to have the best possible value proposition for buyers and sellers in our platform. We want to present users the best speed, the best prices, the best payment alternatives available for them, and we want them to buy more. And when they buy more, they will generate more demand for our seller base. And we believe it's natural for us to put in our storefront, the items that do generate the best experience for the customers. And with that to generate higher sales for our consumers. And that's why we are introducing this system in order to make sure that our buyers always see the most competitive offering and the best experience generating items in the MercadoLibre platform

7 | While strategic investments in free shipping, logistics, 1P and credit card have had some margin pressure, faster revenue growth enabled operating leverage with R&D and G&A

Operating income of USD 724 million, grew by 30% YoY. This demonstrates our ability to balance growth investments and profitability and the power of scale, which should continue to play in our favor. Our strategic investments in free shipping, logistics, 1P and credit card continued to deliver strong top line growth while putting some margin pressure. At the same time, this growth has enabled us to scale key OpEx lines such as product development and G&A expenses.

8 | MELI confident that they can compete strongly against Shopee, not doing irrational things, lower free shipping threshold strengthens their competitive position and positions them as the platform of choice for buyers and for sellers in the long run

So over the last 26 years, we've built a business with a formidable value proposition for buyers, for sellers, and this has put us in a position of market leadership. Our own market share in e-commerce has tripled since 2014, it has doubled since the pandemic, but we are still very, very small when you compare our sales in the country with the total retail sales. So the position that we've built with record of NPLs, record and preference, record retention, record conversion.

This is something about the strength of everything we've done. And we are very confident that we can successfully compete against the different players in Brazil in the exact same way that we've been competing with many of them over the last 26 years. I can't speak for other players in the market, but we do not believe that anything we're doing is irrational. Just look at the results we are seeing from the lower free shipping threshold.

That is a very rational move that significantly strengthens our competitive position, our ability to bring people in the online world that were driving satisfaction. We're driving retention. So as long as we maintain the strategy that served us in the past, which is to be always focused on the user and not on our competitors. We are confident that we will be able to be the platform of choice for buyers and for sellers in the long run.

9 | Mercado Pago was extremely solid, strong growth in AUM and credit portfolio without compromising credit quality

Mercado Pago had a stellar quarter. Monthly active users growth accelerated as our NPS hit record highest in Brazil. This is the result of continued efforts to deliver the best value proposition to our users through UX improvements, our credit card and remunerated account products.  This strong growth in asset under management and credit portfolio reflect the potential of Mercado Pago.

Our credit card, which plays a key role in NPS and principality is growing very rapidly, driven by higher users and share of wallet. We have grown our loan portfolio without compromising credit quality, all-time low first paying depute and more credit cards are reaching maturity.

10 | Lower NIMAL coming mostly from Argentina and increase in funding costs

Tell you a little bit of what has happened lately with NIMAL. I would say that the -- what we have seen is that change in terms of mix basically. We saw a reduction in the last quarter of NIMAL, mostly coming from when you look at the overall credit market, and then I will double-click on credit card. But overall credit, what we saw was a reduction of NIMAL, coming mostly from Argentina and driven by the increase in funding cost we saw last quarter, which was significant because of some stability in the market. But I would say that is rather constrained to that in Argentina, pretty much everything else was working similarly to prior quarters.

11 | Launched no-fee credit card in Argentina, confident of it being a successful product

So I'd say it's still very early to tell. We only launched a credit card in Argentina towards the end of the quarter. So there is not yet enough information. It's too early to comment on its  performance. We -- as we have said in the letter, we are very confident that this will be a successful product because we have a huge user base in Argentina, and they are very engaged with Mercado Pago. And on top of that, because Argentina is a country where most of the credit card -- nearly all of the credit cards charge a monthly fee, and we don't.

12 | Remain disciplined with marketing spending, getting more younger customers, ensure that users are profitable on a unit economics level and are adding to volume sold

In terms of marketing spending, I think if you look at this particular quarter, it was represented about 11% of revenues, which is in line with what we saw last quarter in Q2. As we mentioned last quarter, we were stepping up a little bit of investment in user acquisition in terms of performance plus our affiliate channel. We invested more in our final channel, which grew by 4x year-on-year, this is the way to attract new segments of the population, in particular, younger people and has been a very effective way of bringing more volume to our platform.

So I think going forward, will continue with a similar range of investment. And as we said in the past, we are acquiring users. We have a very sophisticated methodology to acquire users to make sure that those users that we bring are actually contributing to profitability and are adding to the volume sold on our ecosystem. So we're very confident that the level of investment is the right one to support the growth that we are delivering quarter after quarter.

13 | Argentina continues to be an important and very profitable market for MELI, because of size and the leadership position they have, will continue to invest, opened 2nd fulfilment center

Argentina continues to be a very important market for us, not only because of the size of the opportunity but because of the leadership position that we have in the country.  So we, as always, we remain much more focused on continue to improve the value proposition. As we always said, more than macro, the important thing about our business is what we do with our users and our platform. So we continue to invest in Argentina. We opened the second fulfillment center this quarter.

So we are used to managing volatility. I think this quarter as an example to that. And then looking ahead, we think that hopefully some of the volatility will go away after the results of the elections. I will continue to be very optimistic in Argentina for the long time. It continues to be a very profitable market with a lot of growth potential for us in the future.

14 | Encouraged by Mexico, huge distribution channel allowing them to issue card and credits with low CAC

And then when it comes to credits in Mexico, I think that we are very encouraged by what we're seeing about, by the size of the opportunity, we believe that we have a few advantages. One is the strength of our ecosystem in Mexico which gives us a huge distribution channel and also a lot of insights and that lets us issue cards and issue credits with a very small customer acquisition cost.

When we look at the market in general, we already -- including banks, we are already the second largest financial institution in terms of monthly active users. Already #1 in terms of monthly downloads. So we are seeing how we are gaining a lot of traction in the Mexican market, both in consumer credit and in credit cards.

15 | In process of obtaining banking license for Mexico

this, in some cases, we're able to assess to surveys and in other cases, with open banking data. And I would say we have already put in place the 2 of the most important things. And those are yielding account and a strong trade offering. And we -- what we don't have yet is the ability to collect your salary in the market of power account. In the case of Mexico, this is because we are not yet a bank. We are in the process of obtaining a banking license and that is a requirement. And in the case of Brazil, we -- some people collect a salary in Mercado Pago, mostly through portability. But this still is fully small, and we believe there's a large opportunity there.

16 | MELI remains a 3P company and 1P is only strategically used to fill gaps in selection or price competitiveness that 3P sellers are not able to fill, Casas Bahia helps here

So let me start touching on Casas Bahia. So this is an exciting opportunity for us. I mean, while our 1P business continues to perform extremely well, we grew 1% YoY on FX neutral. Our strategy with 1P has always been to fill the gaps in selection or price competitiveness that 3P sellers were unable to fill. And as many times I've said in this call, we are a 3P preferred companies. And Casas Bahia is a seller that is able to bring more selection competitive prices to a category where we are under-indexing in market share.

17 | MELI growing faster and gaining market share in acquiring in Brazil as a result of GTM change from relying less on 3P to 1P salesforce

What we're seeing is that we are both accelerating and growing faster than the market in Brazil. If you recall, a couple of years ago, we decided to pretty much changed all of our go-to-market strategy in Brazil with regards to in-store to POS, and we were relying a lot on third party.  We started building more on old sales force. We started building more our direct-to-consumers Yes, direct to consumers, both via MercadoLibre and via our own Mercado Pago. And those resulted in acceleration that started, I would say, over a year ago and has remained growing faster than the market for some time now. We are comfortable with that. And sort of the same thing has been happening in online payments.

18 | Excited about Agentic AI, MELI recently launched seller assistant and AI assistant in FinTech

So before jumping into OpenAI, let me say that we are extremely excited about the potential of Agent to enhance discovery, service and productivity within our ecosystem. There are several examples of things that we are doing on that regard. We just launched our own seller assistant, which is a conversational tool that gives sellers personalized advice and recommendations on how to manage data activity in our platform. In FinTech, as you probably know, we just launched our first AI assistant that can help our users with a wide range of tasks like making or scheduling money transfer through a conversation platform, asking for questions on the user's operation and so on.

19 | Continue to reevaluate mid to long term capacity and will invest behind in logistics if need be to serve their customers

But of course, we are always reevaluating the mid- to long-term capacity that we need to deal with the volume that we're bringing. And as part of that ongoing evaluation, we will, for sure, build the required capacity as to deal with the volume that will create. As we said over and over, fulfillment is strategic having speed fast and reliable network turns to be strategic for us in order to continue serving our customers to increase their retention to increase their NPS and we'll continue investing behind logistics as we need to serve our customer.

20 | MELI has been growing >30% for 27 consecutive quarters

On the flip side, we mentioned in the letter, we're going at 39% year-on-year. As I said, 27 consecutive quarters of growth above 30%. This is something that no other public company has delivered of this time frame at the scale that MercadoLibre is doing it. So that obviously is helping us dilute fixed costs and we saw this quarter strong dilution on G&A and product development.

MELI continues to grow as LATAM’s dominant e-commerce and fintech platform with a long growth runway with still low penetration. 📦 Marketplace Growth and Free Shipping Strategy

Total revenues grew 39% year-over-year, continuing a streak of 27 consecutive quarters with growth above 30%, supported by robust marketplace activity in key markets.

In Brazil, lowering the free shipping threshold accelerated gross merchandise volume (GMV) and items sold, with items growing 42% YoY—up from 26% in Q2—fueled by stronger buyer conversion and retention.

The shipping cost per unit in Brazil fell 8% sequentially, as higher volume utilization and slower delivery options allowed for more efficient capacity leverage.

The initiative also contributed to a spike in seller listings, particularly in the BRL 19–79 price range, strengthening supply depth and improving price competitiveness.

🛒 User Acquisition and Engagement

The company added 7.8 million new unique buyers across Latin America in Q3, bringing total active buyers to 75 million, driven by improved user experience and targeted incentives.

Growth was a mix of brand-new users and reactivated customers, supported by the affiliate channel, which grew 4x YoY and helped attract younger demographics.

Conversion rates, purchase frequency, and buyer retention reached record highs in Brazil, Mexico, and other core markets, boosting the overall engagement metrics across the ecosystem.

Marketing spend held steady at 11% of revenue, reflecting disciplined investment in performance marketing and acquisition strategies that prioritize profitable user cohorts.

💳 Mercado Pago and Credit Card Expansion

Mercado Pago monthly active user growth accelerated, with net promoter scores (NPS) reaching record levels in Brazil due to UX improvements and attractive financial offerings.

The credit card portfolio doubled YoY and continues to mature well, with older cohorts (>2 years) now profitable and younger cohorts showing improved repayment behavior.

In Argentina, Mercado Pago launched its credit card late in Q3. While early adoption indicators are promising, management noted it is too early to assess its performance.

Principality—measured as users depositing 50%+ of their income into Mercado Pago—grew by 11 percentage points in Brazil and 2 in Mexico, reflecting deepening user engagement.

🏬 Logistics Optimization and Fulfillment Investment

Fulfillment capacity increased 41% YoY, enabling the company to manage a 28% QoQ surge in volume in Brazil without deviating from planned infrastructure expansion.

No unplanned fulfillment centers were opened, but management confirmed mid-to-long-term capacity planning is ongoing to support sustained demand.

Investments in automation and robotics in fulfillment centers are delivering promising productivity gains in key operational areas like picking and packing.

The “slow shipping” option has proved cost-effective and popular, with further optimizations expected over time to drive incremental efficiency.

🏦 Argentina: Growth Amid Macro Volatility

Despite macroeconomic headwinds and elevated interest rates, Argentina delivered 39% YoY revenue growth in USD and 97% in local currency, with items sold up 34%.

GMV, total payment volume (TPV), and buyers remained resilient, although growth decelerated through the quarter due to election-driven uncertainty.

MercadoLibre opened its second fulfillment center in Argentina and launched the credit card, reflecting long-term confidence in the market.

Management remains optimistic about Argentina’s long-term potential, with strong profitability and solid credit performance despite rising funding costs.

Causa de la sobrepreciación.
La "sobrepreciación" (o prima) del precio oficial en México respecto al internacional no es un fenómeno de mercado libre, sino una política deliberada del gobierno para proteger a los productores locales y garantizar la rentabilidad del cultivo, que es base de la dieta mexicana (tortillas, tamales, etc.). Las causas principales son:
1. Aumento de costos de producción: Han subido 46-50% en los últimos 5 años debido a inflación en insumos (fertilizantes, diésel, semillas), crisis hídrica (sequías en Sinaloa, Sonora y Tamaulipas, afectando ~74% del territorio) y cambio climático (lluvias irregulares). El costo unitario promedio es ~4,101 MXN/tonelada, mientras que el precio internacional puro (3,400 MXN) no cubre ni el 83% de eso, llevando a márgenes de rentabilidad del 12% (vs. 50% en 2022).
2. Caída global de precios internacionales: Han bajado 30-50% desde 2022 (de ~7,000 MXN/tonelada post-invasión rusa a Ucrania a ~3,200-3,400 MXN actual), por sobreproducción mundial y stocks récord. Esto colapsa la rentabilidad en México, donde los precios se alinean parcialmente con la Bolsa de Chicago por el T-MEC (Tratado México-EE.UU.-Canadá), que obliga a usar referencias internacionales para evitar distorsiones comerciales.
3. Protestas y negociaciones políticas: Productores exigen 7,200 MXN/tonelada para cubrir costos y mantener siembras (riesgo de abandono si no). El gobierno respondió con subsidios y precios garantizados para evitar crisis alimentaria, bloqueos (en 20+ estados) y pérdida de autosuficiencia (México produce ~23 millones de toneladas, pero importa 19-24 millones anuales, mayoritariamente amarillo).
4. Dependencia de importaciones y soberanía: México busca reducir importaciones de maíz transgénico de EE.UU. (prohibición en vías de revisión judicial), promoviendo precios altos para maíz blanco nacional. Sin esta prima, la producción caería, elevando precios al consumidor (tortilla podría subir 40% en 2025 por déficits de ~600-700 mil toneladas).

En resumen, la sobrepreciación es una medida de apoyo estatal ante un mercado global deprimido y costos locales elevados, pero genera tensiones con EE.UU. (críticas por "subsidios injustos") y presiones inflacionarias. El nuevo Sistema Mexicano de Ordenamiento de Mercado (instruido por la presidenta Sheinbaum) busca estabilizar precios con acuerdos directos productor-industria.
